text: their point is that the user can download a JS file from server. then the user can always format the data properly offline, but if they want to change it on both platforms, they just update the JS on server side, the server client the JS file and that’s it. No pushing whole app updates, doing QA, the whole apple review shebang for just a minor change.
I get that, but what is stopping you formatting the date in Java?
why do we need Javascript for this
thats the part im missing
because if you want to change the way it formats, you gotta push an update to the whole app
no?
why
thats not what they use it for
well you _could_ get the server side string to what you want to format it to
instead of 3:00pm
yeah. but if they want to change that code, they can change it online in one place for all platforms. also it’s easy to write once and run everywhere.
not really justifying it, but that’s what they mean. the same reason behind all the cross-platform shenanigans
Right but the way they present it is that they cant do a dynamic time display without javascript
I understand the usage as a whole
ios, android web having the same data
but I just can't get my head around why I need Javascript to process a dynamic time, lol

but its minor since you have a contract for each view anyway

and at least you lose the funky generic stuff

text: Otherwise I like the way you do the views
with flowless
its pretty clean
my personal grief at the moment is getting the Flow instance out of the View and giving it to the Presenter
because it's embedded into the Context, right
but I don't want to give the Context to the module
why does the presenter need to know about flow?
so that the View wouldn't have to know about the Navigation, of course
right but you could do that int he activity
no, no i couldn't
lol
but i can do it in the custom view
which is what i do right now
most of the time, anyways. There is one method where the Flow instance is given as a method param to the Presenter
Oh i dont really understand how flowless is working yet havnt studied it
I noticed that after re-reading my code and i was like wtf
What I meant was that I have a single activity wwhich controls the navigation for the whole app
same so far
is that bad do you think?
except the navigation is handled by the Flow
My activity doesnt have a presenter
or anything
I was debating that
its just a standalone
i had to add it to Flowless as a possibility of doing
technically it's all because of Flow's tacky lifecycle integration
i see
in order to support a presenter for the activity, I had to either temporarily save out the saved instance state bundle as a field
or to support the possibility of a "global key" to which I can persist state in Flowless
so that Flowless could handle the "global" state of the main presenter as well
ahh, I leave the responibility of saving view data to each view
so I went with the second option because it's less tacky than a `Bundle tempSavedInstanceState; // tacky workaround to obtain Bundle between onCreate() and onPostCreate()`
that's what i did first and I hated it :stuck_out_tongue:
my actual 'router'/stack doesnt care if you save or not
it's *entirely* because Flow hacks itself in after `onCreate()`
but before `onPostCreate()`
but not always
ahh
so you had to have the bundle for both
i added the global state management to Flow so that you don't have to treat this as two different things
I think I get it, I will have to go more indepth in your example
if you see `MainKey.KEY` anywhere, this is what it is for
I see
this example is about 4x as complex as it should be tbh
ye :slightly_smiling_face:
for two reasons
1.) annotation-based configuration of activity/toolbar/drawer
2.) subscoped dagger components
3.) `BasePresenter` instead of just copying attach/detach

this looks more high-tech
